post.content:
1️⃣3️⃣ Here's the 13th post highlighting key new features of the upcoming v258 release of systemd. #systemd258

One of systemd-resolved's fundamental jobs is to maintain per-interface and global DNS configuration (as well as per-delegate configuration, as described earlier in this series). We always provided D-Bus APIs to query the current state of this, and "resolvectl" to a large degree is just a wrapper around that.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content:
In v258 we updated this area substantially. There's now a Varlink IPC call to subscribe to all DNS configuration changes (io.systemd.Resolve.Monitor.SubscribeDNSConfiguration() on /run/systemd/resolve/io.systemd.Resolve.Monitor).

If you issue this you'll get a stream of updates of the DNS configuration as they happen.

Why is this useful? This is used by systemd-networkd-wait-online's new --dns switch. If specified it will not only wait until a suitable network interface with…

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content: @pid_eins I thought systemd-resolved’s job was to make it impossible for me to control what nameservers were used 😕

lennart_followups.content:
…a suitable IP configuration shows up, but also wait until a DNS configuration is acquired as well, making the whole logic more robust regarding dynamic network configuration.

And in case you wonder what systemd-networkd-wait-online is good for: on systems that boot off the network it makes sense to delay attempts to contact the boot servers until the moment networking is fully established (but no longer), so that no time is wasted on pointless retry cycles unnecessarily.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @amackif yeah, that might help in some scenarios like yours

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content:
@acsawdey @sandro My educated guess is that your network config says: pick up DNS config from IPv6 RA advertisments, and your IPv6 network sends those out.

I have no idea about netplan, I don't grok why one would need that, but maybe check what you configured there.

Also try "networkctl status" which shows you the current configuration in effect.

all_descendants.content: @pid_eins would this help in a situation where on client PC .mount unit would be used to mount samba/NFS share, but via hostname instead of a fixed IP? I was playing with a bunch of options and dependencies that you mentioned a while back, but never managed to make it work.
@amackif yeah, that might help in some scenarios like yours

all_descendants.content: @acsawdey @pid_eins you can configure all of that in networkd. Unlike old resolvconf where you either shell script which is brittle, hardcode one for everything or only rely on DHCP. Systemd offers much needed flexibility and options for VPNs and split network.

all_descendants.content: @sandro @pid_eins Take for example Ubuntu 22.04. It uses systems-resolved but the network is configured with netplan, not systemd-networkd. The netplan yaml gives exactly one nameserver address that is IPv4 on the local network. Querying resolvectl shows that address but also 3 IPv6 addresses. Two of them point to the same name server but the other one is for the default gateway router. This didn't come from resolved.conf, it got automatically added from somewhere.

all_descendants.content: @sandro @pid_eins If I add SYSTEMD_LOG_LEVEL=debug to resolved's config and restart, "journalctl -u systemd-resolved -f" shows me a bunch of messages from it ... but notably nothing like "I added DNS server a.b.c.d from source foo".

all_descendants.content: @acsawdey @sandro @pid_eins netplan is just a layer that shims NetworkManager (mangler) and/or systemd-networkd.

@acsawdey
@pid_eins that's from DHCP or fallback dns. resolve.conf also usually just points to the stub resolver daemon from resolved.

Also netplan ist not the best abstraction.

all_descendants.content: @sandro @pid_eins The system is not using DHCP it has a static IP. The extraneous addresses are not the fallback DNS from the resolved.conf file. The /etc/resolve.conf is the one that resolved generates so that's an output not an input. I can't speak to netplan -- this configuration is very simple and expressing it isn't a problem.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins @sandro If it's IPv6 it must be the router. I still think it's reasonable for resolved to log more of what's going on. This is systemd 249 though, perhaps that's been improved. Thanks for your suggestions!

As much as I like to complain about resolved, I have positive opinions about systemd in general. I really appreciate how easily and concisely you can describe a new service and its dependencies.
